```{=html}




Assumptions
``` ## Assumptions #### Independence of the errors
Correlation($\epsilon_{i}$,$\epsilon_{j}$) = 0, $\forall$ pairs of $i$ and $j$
This means that knowing how far observation $i$ will be from the true regression line tells us nothing about how far observation $j$ will be from the regression line. ## Assumptions {.scrollable} #### Homogeniety of the variance var($\epsilon_{i}$) = $\sigma^2$ Constancy in the scatter of observations above and below the line, going left to right. :::{.fragment} ::: {.cell width='200'} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ## Assumptions #### Heteroskedasticity ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: ## Assumptions #### Linearity
$$ E[y_i|x_i] = \mu_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \times x_i \\ $$
The hypothesis about the variables included in the model (e.g., $x_i$) characterizes the mean well. ## Assumptions #### Normality
$$ \epsilon_i \sim \text{Normal}(0,\sigma) $$
Each $i^{th}$ residual ::: {.incremental} - comes from a Normal distribution with a mean of zero - is symmetrically disributed around zero - varies around zero by $\sigma$, which is the same for each residual. ::: ## Assumption Violations ### Robustness
Linearity and constant variance are often more important than the assumption of normality (see e.g., [Knief & Forstmeier, 2021](https://link.springer.com/article/10.3758/s13428-021-01587-5) and references therein)
::: {.fragment}

This is especially true for large sample sizes

::: ## ```{=html}

Confidence Intervals
``` ## What is a CI? . . . "A confidence interval for a parameter is an interval computed using sample data ... . . . "... by a method that will contain the parameter for a specified proportion of all samples. . . . The success rate (proportion of all samples whose intervals contain the parameter) is known as the confidence level." [R. H. Lock et al. (2020)](https://www.wileyplus.com/math-and-statistics/lock-statistics-unlocking-the-power-of-data-3e-eprof20502/) ## What is a CI? #### Key - the parameter we are trying to estimate is a fixed unknown (i.e., it is not varying across samples) :::{fragment} - the endpoints of our confidence interval are random and will change every time we collect a new data set (the endpoints themselves actually have a sampling distribution!) ::: [More at Stats4Ecologists](https://statistics4ecologists-v2.netlify.app/linreg#confidence-intervals) ## What is a CI? ![](/img/CI.png){fig-align="center"} ## Confidence Intervals #### Normal Approximation ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Get 90% confidence intervals (Type I error = 0.1) c( (preds$fit+preds$se.fit*qnorm(0.05))[1], (preds$fit+preds$se.fit*qnorm(0.95))[1] ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1 1 9.623448 10.204195 ``` ::: ::: :::{.fragment} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} CI.Normal=confint(model1.0, level=0.9) CI.Normal ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 5 % 95 % (Intercept) 9.620705 10.20694 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Bootstrapping Instead of relying on the 95% intervals from an assumed normal distribution, we will create a distribution by resampling our data.
See, [Stats4Ecologists](https://fw8051statistics4ecologists.netlify.app/boot.html) ## Bootstrapping (idea) ![](/img/fieberg0.png){fig-align="center" width="450"} ## Bootstrapping (idea) ![](/img/fieberg1.png){fig-align="center" width="450"} ## Bootstrapping (idea) ![](/img/fieberg3.png){fig-align="center" width="450"} ## Bootstrapping (code) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Setup nboot <- 1000 # number of bootstrap samples nobs <- length(y) bootcoefs <- rep(NA, nboot) # Start loop for(i in 1:nboot){ set.seed(43243+i) # Create bootstrap data set by sampling original observations w/ replacement bootdat <- y[sample(1:nobs, nobs, replace=TRUE)] # Calculate bootstrap statistic glmboot <- glm(bootdat ~ 1) bootcoefs[i] <- coef(glmboot) } ``` ::: ## Bootstrapping (code) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) hist(bootcoefs, main = expression(paste("Bootstrap distribution of ", hat(beta)[0])), xlab = "") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Bootstrapping (code) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Calculate bootstrap standard errors boot.se = sd(bootcoefs) # boostrap-normal CI boot.normal = c( (preds$fit+boot.se*qnorm(0.05))[1], (preds$fit+boot.se*qnorm(0.95))[1] ) # bootstrap percentile confdat.boot.pct <- quantile(bootcoefs, probs = c(0.05, 0.95)) ``` ::: ## Comparison ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-22-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## ```{=html}




Case Study /
Independent Variables
``` ## Prairie Dog Calling {.scrollable} ::: {.cell} ::: ![](/img/pdog.png){fig-align="center" width="1200"} y = # of calls per 5 minute at a prairie dog colony temp = temperature, degrees F dist.human = distance of nearest human activity to colony ::: {.fragment} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} head(dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` y temp dist.human 1 0.38129119 39.96298 11.75578 2 0.57770546 47.95317 14.63583 3 0.00347806 56.13182 22.89228 4 0.00000000 29.76491 21.14168 5 2.67643282 40.25998 32.41442 6 1.71519689 38.31469 35.99573 ``` ::: ::: ::: ## Exploratory {.scrollable} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-2.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-3.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Model Fitting 1 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} model = lm(y ~ temp+dist.human, data=dat) summary(model) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: lm(formula = y ~ temp + dist.human, data = dat) Residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -5.6714 -1.6690 -0.1506 1.4910 5.0041 Coefficients: Estimate Std. Slopes do not change. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} model = lm(y ~ I(temp - mean(temp)) + dist.human, data=dat) summary(model) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: lm(formula = y ~ I(temp - mean(temp)) + dist.human, data = dat) Residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -5.6714 -1.6690 -0.1506 1.4910 5.0041 Coefficients: Estimate Std. Marginal Predictions $$ \hat{\mu_{i}} = \hat{\beta_{0}} + \hat{\beta_{1}}\times 0 + \hat{\beta_{2}} \times \text{dist.human}_i $$ ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Plot marginal predictions of dist.human marginaleffects::plot_predictions(model, condition=c("dist.human")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-34-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Combined Predictions 2 {.scrollable} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-39-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Evaluating Assumptions ### Largely done based on the residuals $y_{i} - \hat{y}_{i}$ ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} hist(model$residuals) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-40-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: ## Linearity Assumption ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(model,1) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-41-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: Ideally, there will be no pattern and the red line should be roughly horizontal near zero. ## Homogeneity of Variance ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(model,3) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-42-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: Residuals should be spread equally along the ranges of predictors. We want a horizontal red line; otherwise, suggests a non-constant variances in the residuals (i.e., heteroscedasticity). ## Normality of Residuals ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(model,2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](VariableComb_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-43-1.png){fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: Shows theoretical quantiles versus empirical quantiles of the residuals.
